newsitem.title: SWEDEN: SWIMMING-THOMPSON FINDS LESS PRODUCES MORE.
newsitem.headline: SWIMMING-THOMPSON FINDS LESS PRODUCES MORE.

text.p: Jenny Thompson has found less produces more at the world short-course championships.
On Saturday the 24-year-old pre-med student upstaged fellow-American Misty Hyman with a world record of 57.79 seconds in the women's 100 metres butterfly.
Two days ago, Thompson won gold in the 100 metres freestyle followed on Friday by a silver in the 50 metres freestyle.
"Since the Olympics I've been not having a normal, real tedious, workout schedule. I've been training a lot of the time just once a day, I don't really worry about practice too much," Thompson said.
"I'm just having a lot of fun and my performance here shows that maybe I don't need to train that much."
Underwater exponent Hyman had been widely fancied in the 100 metres final.
She eventually finished third, but along with second-placed Cai Huijue, of China, bettered the previous mark of 58.24 seconds set in 1982 by Japan's Ayari Aoyama, another submarine swimmer.

Thompson, who does not use the style, says that she no longer finds it intimidating in competitors, but thinks that a rule limiting the underwater portion of backstroke races to 15 metres at a time should be extended to other strokes.

"I think it used to make me uncomfortable a little bit because they get such a lead in the beginning, but I know that it hurts them in the end of the race, because the lactic acid buildup is a lot more," she said.

"I've had good success swimming on top of the water, so I guess I'm just old school. I've started using a little bit of underwater, more than I had, but I don't think I'll ever do the sort of swimming that they do," she added.
Of Saturday's triumph she said that the energy of more than 6,000 enthusiastic spectators gave her a boost, even though she knew that the mostly home crowd were cheering Sweden's Johanna Sjoberg.

"I was really fired up before the race because the crowd was going crazy and I knew it was for the Swedish girl but I was trying to use that energy and pretend that they were cheering for me," she said.
